Digital Plagiarism

Understanding academic honesty and digital content originality

What is Digital Plagiarism?

Digital plagiarism is the act of copying information, text, images, code, or academic work from online sources without proper acknowledgement. It violates academic integrity and ethical standards in IT and education.

Forms of Digital Plagiarism

Copy & Paste Plagiarism

Taking content directly from websites or documents without crediting the original creator.

Code Plagiarism

Copying programming code from online platforms without referencing the author.

Image & Media Plagiarism

Using photos, videos, or designs without permission or attribution.

Academic Dishonesty

Submitting essays or project work downloaded from the internet as personal work.

How to Avoid Digital Plagiarism

Use Citation

Always cite original authors using accepted citation styles.

Use Plagiarism Checkers

Tools like Turnitin, Grammarly, and Copyscape help verify originality.

Paraphrase Properly

Rewrite content in your own words while giving credit to the source.

Respect Copyright

Obey copyright rules and Creative Commons licenses when using digital materials.

  • 3. Name one method to avoid plagiarism.
